content: The Act is titled the "Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009" and includes definitions for various terms. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 has been amended to include definitions for "private fund" and "foreign private fund adviser." A private fund is an issuer that would be an investment company under the Investment Company Act of 1940 but for certain exceptions. A foreign private fund adviser is an investment adviser without a place of business in the US, with fewer than 15 US clients and assets under management of less than $25,000,000 attributable to US clients. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 has been amended to include definitions for "private fund" and "foreign private fund adviser." A private fund is an issuer that would be an investment company under the Investment Company Act of 1940 but for certain exceptions. A foreign private fund adviser is an investment adviser without a place of business in the US, with fewer than 15 US clients and assets under management of less than $25,000,000 attributable to US clients. The Act also specifies criteria for exemption from registration as an investment adviser in the US. SEC. 3. ELIMINATION OF PRIVATE ADVISER EXEMPTION; LIMITED EXEMPTION FOR FOREIGN PRIVATE FUND ADVISERS; LIMITED INTRASTATE EXEMPTION. Section 203(b) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exceptions for investment advisers to private funds and foreign private fund advisers. Additionally, the amendment specifies that small business investment companies and entities receiving funding from the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 are exempt from certain requirements. The amendment to Section 203(b) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 includes exceptions for investment advisers to private funds and foreign private fund advisers. It also exempts small business investment companies and entities funded by the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 from certain requirements. SEC. 4. COLLECTION OF SYSTEMIC RISK DATA. Section 204 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require investment advisers to maintain records and file reports regarding private funds advised by them for the protection of investors and assessment of systemic risk. The Commission can share this information with the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and other entities responsible for systemic risk. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require advisers to maintain and file reports on private funds they advise. This information can be shared with the Federal Reserve and other entities responsible for systemic risk. The reports must include details on assets under management, leverage, credit risk exposures, trading positions, and other relevant information. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require advisers to maintain and file reports on private funds they advise. The reports must include details on leverage, counterparty credit risk exposures, trading and investment positions, trading practices, and other necessary information determined by the Commission. Additionally, the Commission may require additional information from private fund advisers based on the public interest and potential systemic risk. The Commission may set different reporting requirements for private fund advisers based on fund types or sizes. Advisers must maintain records of private funds for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. The Commission can conduct periodic examinations of these records. The Commission may conduct periodic examinations of records maintained by private fund advisers registered under the Act. Advisers must make records available to the Commission upon request. The Commission also shares information with the Federal Reserve and other entities for systemic risk assessment. The Commission shares private fund information with the Federal Reserve and other entities for systemic risk assessment, keeping the information confidential as per established rules. Investment advisers must provide reports and documents to investors, counterparties, and creditors as prescribed by the Commission. Investment advisers registered under the Act must provide reports and documents to investors, counterparties, and creditors of private funds as prescribed by the Commission. The Commission is not required to disclose these reports, maintaining confidentiality, but can share information with Congress, other federal agencies, or self-regulatory organizations upon request. The Commission is not obligated to disclose reports to investors, counterparties, or creditors of private funds but may share information with Congress, federal agencies, or self-regulatory organizations upon request or court order. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to eliminate a disclosure provision and provide exemptions and reporting requirements for venture capital fund advisers and certain private fund advisers. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to provide exemptions and reporting requirements for private fund advisers with assets under management below $150,000,000. The Commission will require exempted advisers to maintain records and provide necessary reports for investor protection. Additionally, regulations will be prescribed for mid-sized private fund advisers. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to provide exemptions and reporting requirements for private fund advisers with assets under management below $150,000,000. The Commission will require exempted advisers to maintain records and provide necessary reports for investor protection. Regulations will be prescribed for mid-sized private fund advisers, taking into account their size, governance, and investment strategy to determine systemic risk and establish registration and examination procedures accordingly. SEC. 8. CLARIFICATION OF RULEMAKING AUTHORITY. Section 211 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to grant the Commission authority to make, amend, and rescind rules and regulations necessary for its functions. This includes classifying persons and matters based on various criteria, prescribing different requirements for different classes, and assigning different meanings to terms. The Commission is granted authority to make rules and regulations under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940, including classifying persons and matters, prescribing different requirements, and assigning different meanings to terms. The Commission, along with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, must jointly establish rules for reports to be filed within 12 months of the Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009. The Commission, in consultation with the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, must jointly establish rules within 12 months of the Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009 for reports to be filed by investment advisers registered under both the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and the Commodity Exchange Act. SEC. 9. GAO STUDY. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to assess the costs on industry members and investors due to registration and reporting requirements. A report will be submitted to Congress within 2 years. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE; TRANSITION PERIOD. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE; TRANSITION PERIOD. This Act and its amendments will take effect for investment advisers after a 1-year transition period from the enactment date. The Securities and Exchange Commission will establish rules allowing advisers to register before the deadline. SEC. 11. QUALIFIED CLIENT STANDARD. Section 205(e) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require the Commission to adjust for inflation every 5 years any dollar amount test used in making determinations under this subsection. Adjustments not a multiple of $1,000 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $1,000.
